body:
> The resources method is essentially a macro that applies a set of common patterns to generate routes...

Agreed, but there's plenty of room to customize already, you can use :scope to prefix the routes and :as to override the default name. The one part you can't tailor is the key for the identifier. 

The pain comes in when you have the following route:
```ruby
resources :users
```
and a model for which you don't want to expose a sequential id (perhaps to guard the total user count)
```ruby
def to_param
  self.api_key #GUID
end
```
and finally in your controller you are currently forced to do something offensive like this:
```ruby
class UsersController
  ...
  def show
    @user = User.find_by_api_key(params[:id])
  end
  ...
end 
```
But wait, what's in params[:id]? Was it a sequential id? Was it a GUID? It's not clear from the code. Nor are my expectations of what's in the params very clear for anyone trying to figure out how to call my controller. 

This pull request makes it easy to adhere to conventions, which is especially powerful when exposing an API to third parties who would rather see convention than wade through documentation. By adding the :id_as option, the controller becomes more expressive to the developer while still lending itself to the standard restful routes.

Assuming that all makes sense, Ryan and I will resubmit, addressing the nested routes and base our branch off master.
